intro: Whitleya tangutica, commonly known as the Tangutian bellflower, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue to purple flowers that bloom in summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 centimeters and has lance-shaped leaves with a rough texture. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in alpine meadows and rocky slopes. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is occasionally cultivated in botanical gardens.
